adbk11874.content:
About Address Book

Address Book provides a flexible and convenient way to store contact information for family, friends, and colleagues. Because Address Book is integrated with Mail, iCal, iChat, and other applications, you can enter contact information once and access it from multiple applications.

You can create accounts to access contact information in directories hosted on network servers, such as Microsoft Exchange Global Address Lists (GALs), Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) servers, or online, such as through iCloud or Yahoo!. You can choose to use the same information to set up accounts in Mail and iCal, so you can also access email messages and share calendars hosted on the servers.

You enter contact information in cards. You can import existing contact information from other applications in a variety of formats. You can merge cards and create groups of contacts, including Smart Groups that update themselves when a member’s contact information changes. You can print contact lists, mailing labels, envelopes, and pocket address books to have on hand when a computer isn’t available.

You can do a number of other tasks using Address Book. For example, you can map addresses, send email messages, open websites, track birthdays, and start FaceTime video calls.

If you use Pages, you can insert contact information from your address book, or from a virtual address card (vCard) that someone has sent you, into Pages documents. This feature, sometimes called “mail merge,” makes it possible to reuse a letter, contract, envelope, or other document for multiple people.

Related Topics
Add accounts
Add or edit contacts
Keyboard shortcuts
Why Address Book connects to the Internet
adbk11874.name: About Address Book
adbk11874.summary: Store contact information online and share it with other applications.

adbk19540.content:
Organize contacts by group membership

You can create a Smart Group to organize contacts in your address book who are or are not members of a group or Smart Group. This can be useful, for example, to quickly find contacts that you added to your address book on a mobile device, such as your iPhone, after you sync your iPhone with your computer, so that you can then add the contacts to groups.

  1. Choose File > New Smart Group.
  2. Enter a name for the group.
  3. Specify search criteria.

    From the first pop-up menu, choose Card. From the second pop-up menu, choose either “is member of” or “is not member of.” From the last pop-up menu, choose a specific group or “any group.”

  4. Click OK.
Related Topics
Use Smart Groups
adbk19540.name: Organize contacts by group membership
adbk19540.summary: Create a Smart Group to organize contacts by group membership after synchronizing your iPhone with your computer.

adbk19554.alternativeName: Sync contacts with Yahoo! Address Book
adbk19554.content:
Sync contacts with Yahoo! Address Book

You can sync contacts in your address book with your Yahoo! address book. If you sync your address book with multiple Mac computers, use just one of those computers to sync with your Yahoo! address book. You can’t sync contacts from a CardDAV, Exchange, or Google Contacts account with your Yahoo! address book.

Warning: Do not sync contacts for a Yahoo! account that you have already added to Address Book. Doing so duplicates contacts and, if you delete the duplicates, all Yahoo! contacts are deleted from Address Book and from your Yahoo! address book.
  1. Choose Address Book > Preferences, click Accounts, choose On My Mac in your list of accounts, and then click Account Information.
  2. Select the “Synchronize with Yahoo!” checkbox.
  3. Read the advisory information, and then click Agree to continue.
  4. Enter your Yahoo! ID and password, and then click OK.

    When the Yahoo! ID and password you entered are confirmed, the dialog disappears. You can close Address Book preferences now if you want. Contacts will be synced automatically at a regular interval.

If you later add your Yahoo! account to Address Book, the syncing is disabled.

If you change your Yahoo! ID or password, click Configure to use the new ID or password to sync your contact information.

If you connect an iPhone to your Mac, the Yahoo! ID and password you entered in Address Book automatically appear in iTunes so that your iPhone contacts can be synced with your Yahoo! address book. See the iPhone User Guide for more information about syncing your iPhone with Yahoo! Address Book.

If numerous changes are detected during syncing, an alert is displayed; you can choose to continue or cancel the sync. If duplicate contacts are detected, you’re asked if you want to merge or replace data.

Syncing won’t delete any contact in Yahoo! Address Book that contains a Messenger ID, even if you deleted the contact from your address book or from your iPhone. To delete a contact containing a Messenger ID, log in to your Yahoo! account and delete the contact using Yahoo! Address Book online.

Related Topics
Sync contacts using MobileMe or iTunes
Sync contacts with Google Contacts
adbk19554.name: Sync contacts with Yahoo! Address Book
adbk19554.summary: Synchronize your address book on your Mac with your Yahoo! address book.

adbk21507.content:
Sync contacts with Google Contacts

You can sync contacts in your address book with your Google Contacts. If you sync your address book with multiple Mac computers, use just one of those computers to sync with Google Contacts. You can’t sync contacts from a CardDAV, Exchange, or Yahoo! account with Google Contacts.

Important: If syncing with Google Contacts is turned on when you add an iCloud account, the syncing option is turned off. It’s recommended to keep it turned off while you’re using the iCloud Contacts service.
  1. Choose Address Book > Preferences, click Accounts, choose On My Mac in your list of accounts, and then click Account Information.
  2. Select the “Synchronize with Google” checkbox.
  3. Read the advisory information and then click Agree to continue.
  4. Enter your Google account name (such as you@gmail.com or, for Google Apps customers, you@yourcompanyname.com) and password, and then click OK.

    • You can sync only one Google account.

    • When the account name and password you entered are confirmed, the dialog disappears. You can close Address Book preferences now if you want. Contacts will be synced automatically at a regular interval.

If you change your Google account name or password, click Configure to use the new account name or password to sync your contact information.

If numerous changes are detected during syncing, an alert is displayed; you can choose to continue or cancel the sync.

For more information about Google Contacts, visit:

Google Contacts help webpage

Related Topics
Sync contacts using MobileMe or iTunes
Sync contacts with Yahoo! Address Book
adbk21507.name: Sync contacts with Google Contacts
adbk21507.summary: Synchronize your address book on your Mac with your Google Contacts.

adbk27078.content:
Share your card

You can select which information on your card to share with your contacts when you send them your card. For example, share just your business phone number and keep your home phone number private.

  1. Choose Address Book > Preferences, and then click vCard.
  2. Select “Enable private me card” and then close the preferences window.
  3. In the Address Book window, select your card and click the Edit button.
  4. Select the checkboxes next to the information you want to share.

By default, notes and photos are included when you export your card. To exclude these fields, select the appropriate options in Address Book vCard preferences.

Related Topics
Share address cards by email
Notify contacts when your vCard changes
If an application can’t import your vCard
adbk27078.name: Share your card
adbk27078.summary: Share selected information with contacts when you send them your vCard.

adbk27079.alternativeName: Change the format of phone numbers
adbk27079.content:
Change the format of phone numbers

You can choose how to display phone numbers in your address book to reflect the standard for your country or the country of a contact. Address Book has a default set of formats you can edit, or you can create custom formats.

  1. Choose Address Book > Preferences, and then click Phone.

    If necessary, click the disclosure triangle to show the list of formats.

  2. Change or create formats.

    To learn more about the options, click the Help button.

After you change the phone format, Address Book displays all phone numbers in the new format, regardless of how you type them.

Changing the format of phone numbers doesn’t automatically add country codes to phone numbers.

Related Topics
Change the format of addresses
adbk27079.name: Change the format of phone numbers
adbk27079.summary: Display phone numbers using the standard for your country or the country of your contacts.

adbk27083.content:
Change the card template

You can edit the card template and choose the fields that appear on new cards by default. Existing cards are not affected by changes to the template.

  1. Choose Address Book > Preferences, and then click Template.
  2. Add or remove fields.

    To learn more about the options, click the Help button.

Custom labels that you use in the card template aren’t applied to cards for contacts in Exchange accounts.

Related Topics
Change labels on a card
adbk27083.name: Change the card template
adbk27083.summary: Choose the fields that appear on address cards when you add contacts to your address book.

adbk27094.content:
Add Account pane

Use the Add Account pane to enter information when you add a CardDAV, Exchange, Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP), iCloud, or Yahoo! account.

Note: For some account types, you may first need to contact your network server administrator for the information you need to create the account.
OptionDescription

Account Type

From the pop-up menu, choose CardDAV, Exchange, LDAP, iCloud, or Yahoo!.

CardDAV account

 

User name

Enter your account user name, as provided by your server administrator.

Password

Enter your account password, as provided by your server administrator.

Server address

Enter the address of the server your account uses, as provided by your server administrator.

Exchange account

 

Full name

Enter your account name, as provided by your server administrator.

Email address

Enter your account email address, as provided by your server administrator.

Password

Enter your account password, as provided by your server administrator.

LDAP account

 

Server address

Enter the address of the server, as provided by your server administrator.

Server Options

Open the disclosure triangle and then enter a port number for the server, if provided by your server administrator.

If the server uses Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) to provide additional security, select the checkbox.

iCloud

 

Apple ID

The Apple ID you use with iCloud.

Password

Enter the password for your Apple ID.

Yahoo! account

 

Yahoo! ID

Enter your Yahoo! email address.

Password

Enter the password for your Yahoo! ID.

Related Topics
What is an Apple ID?
adbk27094.name: Add Account pane
adbk27094.summary: Enter information to set up a CardDAV, Exchange, LDAP, iCloud, or Yahoo! account.

adbk27095.content:
Account Settings pane

Use the Account Settings pane to enter details provided by your server administrator when you add an Exchange or Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) account.

OptionDescription

Exchange account

 

Description

Enter a description of the account, which is used as the account’s name in the Address Book window.

User name

Enter your user name for accessing the server, as provided by your server administrator.

Password

Enter your password for accessing the server, as provided by your server administrator.

Server address

Enter the address for the server, as provided by your server administrator.

Also set up

Select the checkboxes to use the same account information to create Exchange accounts for Mail or for iCal calendars.

LDAP account

 

Description

Enter a description of the account, which is used as the account’s name in the Address Book window.

Search base

Enter the location where Address Book starts searching the server for contacts.

Scope

From the pop-up menu, choose how deep in the server hierarchy you want Address Book to search for contacts.

Authentication

From the pop-up menu, choose None or Simple.

If you choose Simple, enter your user name and password on the LDAP server.
adbk27095.name: Account Settings pane
adbk27095.summary: Enter details provided by your server administrator to set up an Exchange or LDAP account.

adbk27096.content:
Account Information preferences

Use Account Information preferences to view or edit information about each of your Address Book accounts, and to set server options for Exchange and CardDAV accounts.

Note: Before changing settings for some account types, check with your network server administrator.
OptionDescription

All account types

 

Enable this account

Make an account active or inactive. If you deselect a checkbox to disable an account, the account and its contacts are removed from Address Book until you enable the account again.

CardDAV account

 

Description

A description of the account, which is used as the account name in the Address Book window.

User name

Your account user name.

Password

Your account password.

Fetch

The frequency with which your address book refreshes contact information from the account server.

To have Address Book update as needed instead of on a schedule, choose Automatically.

Server address (Server Settings pane)

The server address.

Server path (Server Settings pane)

The path of the server.

Port (Server Settings pane)

The port number the server uses.

When the SSL checkbox is selected, it indicates the server uses additional security.

Exchange account

 

Description

A description of the account, which is used as the account name in the Address Book window.

User name

Your account user name.

Password

Your account password.

Fetch

The frequency with which your address book refreshes contact information from the account server.

To have Address Book update as needed instead of on a schedule, choose Automatically.

Edit Account

Click this button to display your Exchange account in Mail, Contacts & Calendars in System Preferences, where you can edit account information.

Internal server or External server (Server Settings pane)

The address of the internal or external server.

Server path (Server Settings pane)

The path of the internal or external server.

Port (Server Settings pane)

The port number the internal or external server uses.

When the SSL checkbox is selected, it indicates the server uses additional security.

LDAP account

 

Name

Your account name.

Server

The server name.

Port

The port number the server uses.

When the SSL checkbox is selected, it indicates the server uses additional security.

Search Base

The location at which Address Book starts searching the server for contacts.

Scope

How deep in the server hierarchy Address Book searches for contacts.

Authentication

The level of authentication (None or Simple) the server uses.

If the server uses Simple authentication, your user name and password on the server are required.

iCloud

 

Description

The description is used in the Address Book window.

Apple ID

The Apple ID you use with iCloud, such as eharrold@me.com.

Yahoo! account

 

Description

The description is used in the Address Book window.

Yahoo! ID

Your account ID, such as eharrold@yahoo.com.

On My Mac

 

Synchronize with MobileMe

Select the checkbox to use your MobileMe subscription to sync your contacts across computers and devices.

If the synchronize setting in MobileMe is not set, click the MobileMe button to set up syncing in MobileMe. If the button is dimmed, syncing is already set in MobileMe.

Synchronize with Yahoo!

Select the checkbox to sync contacts on your Mac computer with your Yahoo! address book.

If you changed your Yahoo! ID or password, click Configure to use the new ID or password to sync your address book.

Synchronize with Google

Select the checkbox to sync contacts on your Mac computer with your Google Contacts.

If you changed your Google account name or password, click Configure to use the new account name or password to sync your address book.

If syncing with Google Contacts is turned on when you add an iCloud account, the syncing option is turned off. It’s recommended to keep it turned off while you’re using the iCloud Contacts service.

Related Topics
Access contacts using iCloud
Sync contacts using MobileMe or iTunes
Sync contacts with Yahoo! Address Book
Sync contacts with Google Contacts
adbk27096.name: Account Information preferences
adbk27096.summary: View or edit information about your Address Book accounts, including server settings.

adbk27097.content:
Sharing preferences

Use Sharing preferences to manage your subscriptions to other MobileMe members’ address books, and to share your address book over the Internet with contacts who are MobileMe members. You must be signed in to your MobileMe account.

OptionDescription

Name

Contacts who are MobileMe members whose address books you subscribe to.

Allow

Indicates whether the address book owner has given you permission to add, edit, or delete contacts.

Add (+)

Click to subscribe to an address book that another MobileMe member has published on the Internet.

Remove (-)

Click to stop subscribing to an address book.

Share your address book

Select the checkbox to share your address book with other MobileMe members.

Name

Contacts who are MobileMe members whom you have selected to share your address book.

Allow Editing

Select the checkbox to allow contacts to change your address book.

Add (+)

Click to select contacts who are MobileMe members whom you want to access your address book.

If you want a contact to be able to change your address book, select Allow Editing for that contact.

Remove (-)

Click to remove contacts from the list so they no longer access your address book.

Send Invitation

Click to let the contacts listed know they can access your address book.

When you move your MobileMe subscription to iCloud, your address book is no longer shared, and other MobileMe users can no longer access it. For more information about iCloud, visit the:

iCloud website

Related Topics
Subscribe to address books
Share your address book
adbk27097.name: Sharing preferences
adbk27097.summary: Subscribe to address books other MobileMe members share over the Internet, and share your own address book.

adbk27471.content:
Add accounts

If you have access to network servers that host contact information (for example, through your workplace or an Internet account such as Yahoo!), you can create an account in Address Book to access the hosted contact information. You can create CardDAV, Exchange, Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP), iCloud, or Yahoo! accounts.

For some accounts, you may first need to contact the network server administrator for the information you need to create the account.

Add an account

  1. Choose Address Book > Preferences, and then click Accounts.
  2. Click Add (+) in the lower-left corner of the Accounts pane.
  3. Select an account type and provide the information requested.

    For a description of the options, click the Help button.

  4. When you’re done, click Create.

    The Address Book account assistant finds any accounts associated with the information you provided and uses settings for those accounts to create your account.

    For some accounts, if Address Book can’t complete the process, it displays the Account Settings pane, where you can enter more detailed information. To display the Account Settings pane yourself, hold down the Option key while you move the pointer over the Create button, and then click it when the label changes to Continue.

Set account preferences

  1. Select an account in the Accounts list.
  2. To specify how often you want your computer to update the information it shares with the server, choose an option from the “Refresh contacts” pop-up menu.

    For example, choose “Every 5 minutes” to check frequently for updated contact information. To have Address Book update as needed instead of on a schedule, choose Automatically.

For a description of other options, click the Help button in the lower-right corner of a pane.

If syncing with Google Contacts is turned on when you add an iCloud account, the syncing option is turned off. It’s recommended to keep it turned off while you’re using the iCloud Contacts service.

If you add a Yahoo! account to which your address book is already synced, the syncing option is automatically deselected.

You can also add accounts in System Preferences.

Open Mail, Contacts & Calendars preferences

Related Topics
Add or edit contacts
Create groups or folders
Access contacts using iCloud
adbk27471.name: Add accounts
adbk27471.summary: Add a CardDAV, Exchange, LDAP, iCloud, or Yahoo! account to access contact information on network servers.

adbk29160.alternativeName: Invite contacts to an iCal event
adbk29160.content:
Invite contacts to an iCal event

You can quickly invite specific contacts or all the contacts in a group or Exchange folder to an iCal event.

  1. Make sure iCal is open.

    Open iCal

  2. In Address Book, select one or more contacts or groups.
  3. Drag the selected contacts or groups to a date in a calendar in the iCal window.

    iCal creates the event and displays the event window, where you can specify the time and other details for the event. Your contacts are listed as invitees in the event window.

    For more information about setting up an event, read this iCal help topic:

    Add events to a calendar

  4. When you’re done setting up the event, click Send in the event window.
Related Topics
Invite contacts to text chats
Send email messages
Make a FaceTime video call
adbk29160.name: Invite contacts to an iCal event
adbk29160.summary: Invite specific contacts or all contacts in a group or Exchange folder to an iCal event.

adbk35489.content:
Address Book Help

Address Book Help

Store, sync, and share contact information and use it in messages, chats, events, and more.
adbk35489.name: Address Book Help

adbk35728.content:
Account Summary pane

Use the Account Summary pane to review the account information you entered, before the account is created.

OptionsDescription

Full name

Your account user name.

Email address

Your account email address (for example, your Yahoo! email address).

Server address

The server address. This information is automatically generated based on the email address you entered.

Also set up

By default, the same account information can be used to create Mail, iCal, or iChat accounts for you. If you don’t want to create one of these accounts, deselect its checkbox.
adbk35728.name: Account Summary pane
adbk35728.summary: Use this pane to review information entered when adding certain accounts.

adbk35804.alternativeName: Manage your contacts from one address book
adbk35804.content:
Manage your contacts from one address book

Address Book offers a flexible and convenient place to store contact information for your family, friends, and colleagues. Because Address Book is integrated with Mail, iChat, and other applications, you can enter contact information once and have instant access to it from multiple applications.

Open Address Book

Add contacts from your accounts

  • When you add your iCloud, MobileMe, or Yahoo! account to Address Book, all the contact information from those accounts appears in Address Book. The information is automatically updated, so you can manage all of your contacts from a single address book.

  • You can also add workplace contacts hosted on network servers, such as Microsoft Exchange servers.

    Add accounts

Import contacts

Another way to add contacts is to import them from other applications. Because Address Book uses the common vCard format for storing contact information, your friends can send you cards that you can drop into your address book — no typing required.

To import a contact, choose File > Import and select a vCard, or drag a vCard into the Address Book window. For more information, read this Address Book help topic:

Import contacts

Add a new contact

It’s easy to add a new contact. Choose File > New Card or click Add (+) and enter your contact’s information. For more information, read this Address Book help topic:

Add or edit contacts

Use contact information

Address Book does more than store contact information; it also lets you use that information. Click an address to see a Google map of the location. Click a URL to open the website. Click an email address to instantly send an email or start a FaceTime video call. You can also print your contacts as a list, mailing labels, and more.

For more information about making video calls or sending messages using your contacts, read these Address Book help topics:

Make a FaceTime video call

Send email messages

Keep contacts up to date from anywhere

If you have an iCloud account and Mac OS X 10.7.2, you can turn on the iCloud Contacts service on your iOS 5 devices and your computers, and have instant access to current contact information anytime you need it. For example, if you change a contact’s phone number in Address Book on your Mac, the change is instantly uploaded to iCloud and then pushed to your other devices. For more information about iCloud, visit the:

iCloud website
adbk35804.name: Manage your contacts from one address book
adbk35804.summary: Centralize contact information from all your accounts in Address Book and use the information in multiple applications.

adbk35836.content:
Make a FaceTime video call

If you have installed FaceTime and your Mac computer or display has a built-in camera, you can call FaceTime users from your address book. To place a video call to an iPhone user, you use the contact’s phone number. To call other Mac users or iPod touch and iPad users, you use the contact’s email address.

  1. Select a contact.

    Display contacts or groups

  2. Click the contact’s phone number or email address and select FaceTime from the pop-up menu.

    FaceTime opens.

  3. Sign in to FaceTime using an existing Apple ID, or create one.

    What is an Apple ID?

For more information about FaceTime, read this FaceTime help topic:

Make video calls

Related Topics
Send email messages
Invite contacts to an iCal event
Invite contacts to text chats
adbk35836.name: Make a FaceTime video call
adbk35836.summary: Make a FaceTime video call to a contact using the contact’s phone number or email address.

adrbk1003.content:
Sort contacts

You can choose to sort contacts in your address book by either first or last name.

  1. Choose Address Book > Preferences, and then click General.
  2. Use the Sort By pop-up menu to choose whether to sort by first or last name.
Related Topics
Display contacts or groups
adrbk1003.name: Sort contacts
adrbk1003.summary: Use the Sort By pop-up menu in the General pane of Address Book preferences to choose how to sort contacts.

adrbk1005.content:
Use Smart Groups

A Smart Group is a collection of contacts that Address Book automatically updates with contacts that fit criteria you specified for the group. For example, create a Smart Group for all the members of your swim club by searching for “swim” in the notes field. Then every time you enter “swim” in a contact’s notes field, the contact is automatically added to your swim club Smart Group. Smart Groups can include contacts from any account.

Create a Smart Group

  1. Choose File > New Smart Group.
  2. Enter a name for the Smart Group.
  3. Specify the conditions.

    • Use the pop-up menus and entry field to set the conditions. Click Add (+) to specify additional conditions.

    • If you include a group in a condition (by choosing “Card is member of” or “Card is not member of”), you can’t delete that group until you either change the condition or delete the Smart Group that uses the condition.

  4. If you want Address Book to highlight a Smart Group’s name whenever it automatically adds or removes a contact, select the “Highlight group when updated” checkbox.
  5. Click OK.

Edit a Smart Group

Control-click the group and choose Edit Smart Group from the pop-up menu, or choose Edit > Edit Smart Group.

Rename a Smart Group

Double-click the group and enter a new name.

You can use a Smart Group to find contacts that you added to your address book on a mobile device, such as your iPhone, after you sync your iPhone with your computer.

Organize contacts by group membership

Related Topics
Create groups or folders
adrbk1005.name: Use Smart Groups
adrbk1005.summary: Use Smart Groups to create groups that are automatically updated.

adrbk1006.content:
Share your address book

If you have a MobileMe subscription, you can share your address book over the Internet with friends, family, and colleagues who have MobileMe subscriptions.

  1. Sign into your MobileMe account, if you’re not already signed in.
  2. Choose Address Book > Preferences, click Accounts, select your On My Mac account, and then click Sharing.
  3. Select the “Share your address book” checkbox.
  4. Click Add (+), and then select contacts with MobileMe subscriptions to whom you want to give access to your address book.

    If you want a contact to be able to change your address book, select Allow Editing for that contact.

  5. Click Send Invitation to let the contacts you listed know they can access your address book.

The users you selected can now subscribe to your address book by opening Address Book on their computers and choosing File > “Subscribe to Address Book.”

Subscribe to address books

When you move your MobileMe subscription to iCloud, your address book is no longer shared, and other MobileMe users can no longer access it. For more information about iCloud, visit the:

iCloud website
adrbk1006.name: Share your address book
adrbk1006.summary: With a MobileMe subscription, share your address book with contacts who have MobileMe subscriptions.

adrbk1007.content:
Subscribe to address books

If you have a MobileMe subscription, you can subscribe to address books that other MobileMe members have published on the Internet and have given you permission to access.

  1. Sign into your MobileMe account, if you aren’t already signed in.
  2. Choose File > “Subscribe to Address Book.”
  3. Enter the MobileMe email address of the user and click OK.

You can view the published address book from your computer using Address Book. Changes made by the owner of the address book are immediately visible to you. If the owner of the address book has selected Allow Editing for you, you can add, delete, and edit contacts.

Related Topics
Share your address book
adrbk1007.name: Subscribe to address books
adrbk1007.summary: Subscribe to address books that other MobileMe users have published on the Internet.

adrbk1080.content:
Add or edit contacts

Address Book stores address, telephone, email, profile (such as Twitter or Facebook), and other information about your friends, family, and professional contacts on address cards. You can also add a company, such as the phone or gas company, to your address book.

  1. Add a card by choosing File > New Card, or click Add (+) at the bottom of the Address Book window when viewing the list or a card.

    Edit a card by choosing Edit > Edit Card, or click the Edit button at the bottom of the Address Book window.

    Display contacts or groups

  2. Add or edit contact information, pressing the Tab key to move from field to field.

    • If a field doesn’t apply, leave it blank or click Remove (-) next to the field to delete the information; empty fields aren’t displayed after you save the card.

    • To add a field, choose Card > Add Field and then choose a field from the menu.

    • Some fields, such as phone number, can have multiple entries, such as home, work, or cell phone number. Other fields, such as birthday, have only one entry. To display another entry field, when available, press Return.

    • To change the label for a field, click the current label and choose a different one from the pop-up menu, or choose Custom and create your own label.

    • To indicate the contact is a company, select the Company checkbox. The default picture for a company is a building; you can choose a different picture.

      Show pictures on cards

    • To enter a multi-line address, press Return at the end of the street field. (You can add lines only to the street field.)

  3. Save the card by choosing File > Save, or click the Done button at the bottom of the Address Book window.

When you add a contact to an Exchange account, you can include only three email addresses, labeled as Email 1, Email 2, and Email 3. Similar restrictions also apply to phone numbers, contact names, instant messaging addresses, and street addresses.

You can add or edit notes directly without being in Edit mode.

Related Topics
Import contacts
Export and import vCards
Change the card template
adrbk1080.name: Add or edit contacts
adrbk1080.summary: Use Address Book to store information about friends, family, and professional contacts.

adrbk1178.content:
Create groups or folders

Use groups and folders to organize your contacts by categories, such as family or friends, or to easily send email messages to several people at once. You can create a group for a local, CardDAV, or Yahoo! account, or a folder for an Exchange account.

Contacts in an Exchange account can belong to only one folder at a time. When you first create a folder for an Exchange account, Address Book automatically creates a Contacts folder for the account and adds to it any contact that doesn’t belong to a group.

Create a group or folder

  1. Display the list of groups and select a local, CardDAV, or Exchange account.

    If the list of groups isn’t displayed, choose View > Groups or click the Groups icon at the top of the Address Book window.

  2. Create the group or folder:

    • For a local, CardDAV, or Yahoo! account, choose File > New Group. To create a group from selected contacts, select multiple contacts, choose File > New Group From Selection, and then enter a name for the new group.

    • For an Exchange account, choose File > New Folder.

    • For all three account types, you can click Add (+) at the bottom of the Address Book window and then enter a name for a new group or folder.

Add contacts to a group or folder

Do one of the following:

  • When viewing the list of groups, select one or more contacts and drag them to a group or folder.

    If the list of groups isn’t displayed, choose View > Groups or click the Groups icon at the top of the Address Book window.

  • When viewing the list of contacts and a card, drag one or more contacts to the Groups icon at the top of the Address Book window until the page turns to show the list of groups, and then continue dragging the contacts to the group where you want to add them.

    To display the list and card, choose View > “List and Card” or click the Card icon at the top of the Address Book window.

Contacts for local, CardDAV, or Yahoo! accounts can exist in multiple groups at the same time. When you drag contacts to groups within the same account, the contact is copied to the new location; the contact exists in both the original and the new location.

Contacts for an Exchange account can belong to only one folder at a time. If you drag an Exchange contact from one folder to another, the contact moves from the original to the new location.

You can create subgroups or subfolders by dragging a group or folder to another group or folder.

To see the groups and folders a contact belongs to, select the contact and press the Option key. Address Book highlights the groups and folders containing the contact.

If group members have multiple email addresses, you can choose which address you want to use when sending mail to the group or folder.

Select addresses for group members

You can create a Smart Group that automatically adds or deletes contacts to a group according to search rules that you define.

Use Smart Groups

Related Topics
Delete contacts or groups
adrbk1178.name: Create groups or folders
adrbk1178.summary: Create a group or folder and add contacts to it to help organize your address book.

adrbk1324.content:
Import contacts

Address Book can import contact information that you save or export from other applications in vCard, LDAP Interchange Format (LDIF), tab-delimited, and comma-separated value (CSV) formats.

You can export addresses in vCard format from Entourage, Outlook, and others, and in LDIF format from Thunderbird, for example. You can export text files in tab-delimited or CSV format from spreadsheet applications, such as Numbers.

  1. Export addresses from another application in a supported format.

    • Before exporting tab-delimited or CSV files, you may want to note the order of the information fields, especially if the file doesn’t contain labels. Your notes may help you manually identify fields in a later step.

    • If the application you’re exporting from supports it, export vCards that include multiple contacts to speed up importing. For example, in Outlook select all of your contacts and choose to forward them in an email message as vCards. Send the message, which includes a vCard attachment for each selected contact, to yourself on your Mac computer. In Mail, save the vCard attachments, and then use Address Book to import them.

  2. Verify the exported tab-delimited or CSV file using a text editor such as TextEdit.

    • Make sure there are no line breaks within a contact’s information, which can cause the import to fail. Remove any line breaks you find.

    • Make sure that fields in a tab-delimited file are separated by a tab, and fields in a CSV file are separated by a comma, instead of by quotation marks or another character. Do not include spaces before or after tabs and commas.

    • Make sure all addresses have the same number of fields; add empty fields as needed.

  3. In Address Book, choose File > Import, select the file you want to import, change the encoding if necessary, and then click Open.
  4. If you’re importing a text file, review the field labels Address Book will use for the information. You can change field labels, or choose to ignore or not import fields.

    • If the first card contains headers, review the headers to make sure they are correctly labeled or marked as “Do not import,” and make changes as necessary. Any changes you make to this card are made in all of the cards in the file. To exclude the headers card from being imported, select the “Ignore first card” checkbox.

    • Use the arrows to browse information in the file to determine if fields need to be relabeled or not imported.

    • To change a label, click the arrows next to the label and choose a new label from the pop-up menu. If you don’t want to import a field, choose “Do not import.”

If a card contains custom fields, the information in those fields is not imported.

When you import contacts into an Exchange account, information in Exchange fields that aren’t supported in Address Book are added to the Notes field on the contact’s card.

To see the most-recently imported contacts, display groups and then select the Last Import group. This group is updated each time you import contacts. Use the View menu to show or hide the Last Import group.

Related Topics
Export and import vCards
Add or edit contacts
adrbk1324.name: Import contacts
adrbk1324.summary: Import contact information in various formats, including vCard and LDIF format.

adrbk1451.content:
Set up your card

Address Book automatically creates an address card for you using information you supplied when you first set up your computer. You can add more information to your card.

  1. Select your card.

    Add to it any information you want to include, such as your email addresses, phone numbers, birthday, and so on. You can customize your card by adding a picture; the picture is used for your account and is visible to other users of your computer.

    Show pictures on cards

  2. Choose Card > Make This My Card.

    Other applications on your computer, such as iCal, iChat, and Mail, use information from your “me” card. You can keep some or all of the information on your card private and exclude it when you send your card to contacts.

    Share your card

To quickly display your card at any time, choose Card > “Go to My Card.”

If you have already set a “me” card and try to create a second one (perhaps for a different account), the first “me” card will be unset and the second one will become your “me” card.

Related Topics
Notify contacts when your vCard changes
Share address cards by email
adrbk1451.name: Set up your card
adrbk1451.summary: Ensure the card that contains your information is marked as “me.” This information is used by other applications.

adrbk1453.content:
Add important dates

You can use Address Book to store your contacts’ birthdays, anniversaries, or other important dates.

  1. Display a contact’s card.

    Display contacts or groups

  2. Choose Card > Add Field > Birthday. If you’re adding a date other than a birthday, choose Dates.

    Dimmed fields indicate dates that already appear in the card.

  3. Enter the date, and then click Done to save the changes.

    You don’t need to enter a year.

Related Topics
Show birthdays on an iCal calendar
adrbk1453.name: Add important dates
adrbk1453.summary: Use Address Book to remember birthdays, anniversaries, and other important dates.

adrbk1454.content:
Change the format of addresses

You can change the default address format used for cards in Address Book. For example, display addresses in a format used in another country.

For all cards

  1. Choose Address Book > Preferences, and then click General.
  2. Choose a country or region from the Address Format pop-up menu.

For a single card

  1. Display the card and click Edit.

    Display contacts or groups

  2. Click the label (such as “home”) next to the address you want to change, choose Change Address Format from the pop-up menu, and then select a country or region.

    The country or region you select must match what appears in the contact’s address. If they don’t match, Address Book may not display the correct map when you try to map the address.

    Map an address

Related Topics
Change the format of phone numbers
adrbk1454.name: Change the format of addresses
adrbk1454.summary: Change the default address format used for cards.

adrbk1456.content:
Merge duplicate cards

If you have more than one card for a contact, you can combine them into a single card, preserving all the unique information. The cards you want to merge have to be in the same account, such as a CardDAV account or On My Mac.

Merge all duplicates

  1. Select an account in the list of groups.

    If groups aren’t displayed, click the Groups icon at the top of the Address Book window.

  2. Choose Card > “Look for Duplicates.”

    Address Book alerts you if it finds duplicate cards, as well as cards that have the same contact name but different information. Address Book also alerts you if it finds information duplicated on a single card, such as a card that contains the same email address twice.

  3. Click Merge. If applicable, click the checkbox to also merge cards with the same name but with different information.

    Address Book merges the unique information from each duplicate card into a single card. It uses the picture from the duplicate card that was listed first in the address book.

Merge selected duplicates

Command-click to select the cards you want to combine and choose Card > Merge Selected Cards.

Address Book creates a single card using the name and picture of the card that appeared first in the list.

Related Topics
Resolve duplicate cards when importing cards
adrbk1456.keywords: combine, unclutter, streamline, tips, combining duplicates, duplicates, merging cards
adrbk1456.name: Merge duplicate cards
adrbk1456.summary: Combine duplicate cards into a single card, preserving all of the unique information.

adrbk1457.content:
Archive your address book

You can archive your address book before making extensive changes to it, such as importing new addresses or reorganizing groups. Archiving is also an easy way to create a backup copy of your address book, or to move your address book to another computer.

  1. Choose File > Export > Address Book Archive.
  2. Specify a name for the archive file and select where you want to export the file.

    To further safeguard your address book archive, copy the file to an external hard drive.

If you have made inadvertent changes to your address book, you can import an archive file. If there are new or changed cards you don’t want to lose when you import the archive file, export those cards as vCards first (and then import them after you import the archive file).

Import contacts

Related Topics
Restore address book information
adrbk1457.name: Archive your address book
adrbk1457.summary: Archive your address book before making extensive changes to it or to have a backup copy.

adrbk1493.alternativeName: Display phone numbers in large type
adrbk1493.content:
Display phone numbers in large type

You can temporarily display a phone number in your address book in a very large font to make it easier to see while you’re dialing.

  1. Display a contact’s card.

    Display contacts or groups

  2. Click the phone label (such as “work”), and then choose “Show in Large Type” from the shortcut menu.

    To close the large type display, click anywhere on the screen.
adrbk1493.name: Display phone numbers in large type
adrbk1493.summary: Temporarily display a phone number in large type to make it easier to see while dialing.

adrbk1494.content:
Change labels on a card

You can change the label that appears next to a field on a contact’s card. For example, change “work” to “support” next to a phone number.

  1. Display a contact’s card, and then click the Edit button.

    Display contacts or groups

  2. To display a pop-up menu of labels that are available for a field, click the existing label, and then choose a different label from the pop-up menu.

    To create a custom label, choose Custom from the pop-up menu.

You can’t create custom labels for contacts in Exchange accounts.

Related Topics
Change the card template
adrbk1494.name: Change labels on a card
adrbk1494.summary: Change the label that appears next to a field on a specific card.

adrbk1495.content:
Search for contacts

You can search your address book or your computer for a contact or contact information.

In your address book

  1. Type the text you want to find in the search field.

    As you type, Address Book begins to search contact information, including notes, and displays the count of matching results in the search field as it searches.

  2. To display all your contacts again, remove the text from the search field.

To find contacts in a directory service, you need to search the directory service.

Use network directory services

On your computer

  1. Select the contact you want to find information about.
  2. Control-click the contact and choose Spotlight from the shortcut menu, or choose Edit > Spotlight.

    The results are displayed in a Spotlight search window.

To learn more about Spotlight, read this help topic:

What is Spotlight?

Related Topics
Sort contacts
adrbk1495.name: Search for contacts
adrbk1495.summary: Search your address book or your computer for contacts.

adrbk1498.alternativeName: Resolve duplicate cards when importing cards
adrbk1498.content:
Resolve duplicate cards when importing cards

When you import or add vCards, Address Book checks whether any of the new cards are duplicates of existing cards. If it finds duplicates, you can review the cards and decide to keep the old card, the new card, or both cards, or merge the two cards into one.

  1. Choose File > Import, select a vCard file, and then click Open.
  2. Accept or review duplicate cards.

    • To automatically accept duplicate cards, click Import.

    • To review the duplicate cards and resolve discrepancies between them, click the review button and continue to the next step.

  3. Review the first duplicate.

    Click a card button along the bottom of the window to review these cards: the old card (the one in your address book before you started), the new card (the one you’re importing), both cards in a split window, or an updated card that merges information from both cards.

  4. When you’re done reviewing the card, click a card button to select how to resolve the duplicates. For example, click the Update button to update the card with merged information.
  5. Accept or review other duplicates.

    • To resolve all of the duplicates the same way as the first one, select the “Apply to All” checkbox and then click Import.

    • To continue reviewing and resolving each duplicate, click Next.

Related Topics
Import contacts
Export and import vCards
Merge duplicate cards
adrbk1498.name: Resolve duplicate cards when importing cards
adrbk1498.summary: Resolve duplicate cards by choosing which information to update and to retain.

adrbk1500.content:
Template preferences

Use Template preferences to choose the fields to appear on new cards when you add contacts to your address book. Existing cards in your address book are not affected by changes you make to the template.

OptionDescription

Add Field

From the pop-up menu, choose a field to add to the template. A dimmed field indicates it’s used in the default template. If a field has a checkmark, it has already been added to the template; to remove it, choose it again.

Add (+)

Click Add (+) in the template to allow another entry for a field. The Add button appears only for fields that can have multiple entries, such as Phone.

Remove (-)

Click Remove (-) in the template to remove a field. You can remove only fields that you added to the template.

Label arrows

Click a label in the template and choose a different label for the field from the pop-up menu. To create a custom label, choose Custom.
adrbk1500.name: Template preferences
adrbk1500.summary: Choose the fields to appear on new cards when you add contacts.

adrbk1503.content:
Copy addresses as mailing labels

You can copy an address as a mailing label and paste it into a word processing application, such as Pages, for printing envelopes.

  1. Display a contact’s card.

    Display contacts or groups

  2. Click an address field’s label (such as “work” or “home”), and then choose Copy Mailing Label from the pop-up menu.
adrbk1503.name: Copy addresses as mailing labels
adrbk1503.summary: Click the label of a field and choose “Copy mailing label” from the pop-up menu.

adrbk1504.alternativeName: Notify contacts when your vCard changes
adrbk1504.content:
Notify contacts when your vCard changes

When you change your contact information, you can send a group email message to your contacts. The message contains your updated vCard and a message from you.

  1. If you don’t have a group of addresses, create one.

    Create groups or folders

  2. Choose File > Send Updates.
  3. In the Send Updates dialog, select one or more groups to notify.

    If some contacts in the group have multiple email addresses, you can choose which address to use.

    Select addresses for group members

  4. Type a subject title and a message, and then click Send.
adrbk1504.name: Notify contacts when your vCard changes
adrbk1504.summary: Send a group email message from Address Book.

adrbk1508.content:
Invite contacts to text chats

You can see at a glance if a contact is logged in to iChat, AOL Instant Messenger (AIM), or another chat application, and invite the contact to a text chat.

Click the green circle next to the contact’s picture to invite the contact to chat.

If your contact is online, the circle next to the picture indicates your contact’s iChat status. A green circle indicates the contact is available to chat.

For more information about iChat status indicators, read this iChat help topic:

About the status indicators

Related Topics
Send email messages
Invite contacts to an iCal event
Make a FaceTime video call
adrbk1508.name: Invite contacts to text chats
adrbk1508.summary: See at a glance if a contact is logged in to iChat or another chat application and start a text chat.

adrbk1511.content:
General preferences

Use General preferences to set options for viewing contact information, and to identify the default account to use for new contacts.

OptionDescription

Show first name

Display a contact’s first name before or after the last name.

Sort by

Sort contacts by first name or by last name.

Address Format

Set the country or region whose address formatting you want to use for displaying contacts’ addresses.

Default Account

Select the account to which contacts are added whenever you add a contact using Address Book or Mail (by selecting a sender in a message and then choosing Message > “Add Sender to Address Book”).

This option is displayed only if you have more than one Address Book account.
adrbk1511.name: General preferences
adrbk1511.summary: Set options for viewing contacts and to identify the default account for new contacts.

adrbk1512.content:
vCard preferences

Use vCard preferences to set options for sharing your contact information and for exporting notes and photos.

OptionDescription

vCard Format

Select the format to use for vCards in your address book. The default format is 3.0.

vCard 2.1 Encoding

Select the encoding to use when you’ve selected the 2.1 vCard format.

Enable private me card

Control the information from your own vCard that you share with your contacts.

Export notes in vCards

Include your notes about contacts when you export vCards.

Export photos in vCards

Include images of contacts when you export vCards.

Related Topics
Share your card
Export and import vCards
adrbk1512.name: vCard preferences
adrbk1512.summary: Set options for sharing your contact information and for exporting notes and photos.

adrbk1513.content:
Select addresses for group members

If members of a group have multiple addresses (email or street) or phone numbers, you can select which address or phone number to use when sending a message to that group or when printing contact information. You can manage addresses for individual members of the group, or choose a type of address to use for all members of the group.

  1. Choose Edit > Edit Distribution List.
  2. Select the group whose addresses you want to manage.

    You can’t choose Smart Groups.

  3. Click the rightmost column header to display a pop-up menu for choosing the type of information you want to manage: phone number, email address, or street address.
  4. Select the email or street address, or phone number, you want to use for each member who has more than one email or street address, or phone number.

    You can also change the label that’s used by choosing another label from the Change All Labels pop-up menu.
adrbk1513.name: Select addresses for group members
adrbk1513.summary: Select which address or phone number to use when sending a message to a group or when printing contact information.

adrbk1514.content:
Phone preferences

Use Phone preferences to edit or create formats for displaying phone numbers in your address book.

OptionDescription

Automatically format phone numbers

When this option is selected, Address Book formats phone numbers for you when you enter them. To format phone numbers yourself, deselect this option.

Formats

To choose a different format, select a format from the pop-up menu. To create your own format, choose Custom.

To show or hide a list of formats and examples of each one, click the disclosure triangle.

Add (+)

To create a new format, click Add (+) and type a format in the Format field. For example, to see long-distance phone numbers in the United States displayed as +1(234)567-8910, you would type:

+1(###)###-####

Delete (-)

To delete a format, select it in the list and click Delete (-).

Edit

To change an existing format, double-click the format in the list, or select it in the list and click Edit. Then type your changes.

Address Book changes the format to Custom when you edit an existing format.

Changing the format of phone numbers doesn’t automatically add country codes to phone numbers.
adrbk1514.name: Phone preferences
adrbk1514.summary: Edit or create formats for displaying phone numbers in your address book.

adrbk1515.content:
Delete contacts or groups

You can delete a contact from your address book or just from the groups in which it is included. You can also delete groups.

Delete a contact

  1. Select one or more contacts to delete.
  2. Choose Edit > Delete, or press the Delete key.

    Address Book asks you to confirm the deletion.

    Contacts are removed from your address book, including from any groups in which they were included.

Delete a contact from a group

  1. Select the group the contact belongs to.

    If groups aren’t displayed, click the Groups icon at the top of the Address Book window.

  2. Select the contact and do one of the following:

    • To remove the contact from the group but keep it in your address book, choose Edit > Remove From Group.

    • To delete the contact from all groups and your address book, press the Delete key.

Delete a group

  1. Select a group to delete.

    If groups aren’t displayed, click the Groups icon at the top of the Address Book window.

    Before you can delete a group that’s used in the rule for a Smart Group, you must first edit the Smart Group and remove the group from the rule, or delete the Smart Group.

  2. Choose Edit > Delete, or press the Delete key.

    Address Book asks you to confirm the deletion. To skip the confirmation when you delete groups, press Option and Delete at the same time.

You can’t delete the Contacts group in an Exchange account, or the Last Import Group (when it’s displayed).

Related Topics
Use Smart Groups
adrbk1515.name: Delete contacts or groups
adrbk1515.summary: Remove contacts from your address book or from groups.

adrbk1517.content:
Copy contact information

You can copy contact information and paste it elsewhere, such as in an email message or a document.

  1. Display the contact whose information you want to copy.

    Display contacts or groups

  2. Select the information you want to copy, such as a phone number, choose Edit > Copy, and then paste the information where you want.

You can export one or more cards to include in an email message or an iChat message, or for other uses.

Export and import vCards

Related Topics
Search for contacts
adrbk1517.keywords: person, relay, card, copy, sharing contact information
adrbk1517.name: Copy contact information
adrbk1517.summary: Copy contact information to paste elsewhere.

adrbk1521.content:
If you can’t import contacts

If you have problems importing contacts, you can verify the format of the contact information or check permissions.

  • Make sure the contact information is in a vCard, LDIF (LDAP Data Interchange Format), or tab-delimited or comma-separated value (CSV) text file. To verify the file format, in the Finder, select the file you’re trying to import and choose File > Get Info. The General section displays the kind of file.
  • Review the content of a tab-delimited or CSV file using a text editor, such as TextEdit, for problems that could cause the import to fail (for example, extra line breaks or spaces).

    Import contacts

  • If you can’t import because of permissions errors, in the Finder, select the file you’re trying to import and choose File > Get Info. In the Sharing & Permissions section, choose Read & Write from the Privilege pop-up menu.

LDIF files can be produced by Thunderbird and LDAP servers. vCard files can be produced by Entourage, Outlook, and iPod. Most spreadsheet applications can export tab-delimited or CSV text files.
adrbk1521.name: If you can’t import contacts
adrbk1521.summary: Verify the format of the contact information you’re trying to import.

adrbk1522.alternativeName: If you can’t access a contact’s webpage or iDisk
adrbk1522.content:
If you can’t access a contact’s webpage or iDisk

If an error occurs when you try to visit a contact’s MobileMe iWeb site or web gallery, or open the contact’s iDisk, you may not be connected to the Internet, or the contact’s MobileMe address may have changed.

Check your network and Internet connections, and verify the contact’s MobileMe address.

If you need help connecting to the Internet, read this help topic:

Connect to the Internet
adrbk1522.name: If you can’t access a contact’s webpage or iDisk
adrbk1522.summary: Check your network and Internet connections and make sure the contact’s address is correct.

adrbk1524.content:
Send email messages

You can quickly create a pre-addressed email message using contacts in your address book.

To a contact

  1. Display a contact’s card.

    Display contacts or groups

  2. Click the label of the email address field and choose Send Email from the pop-up menu.

    Your default email application opens and creates a new message addressed to the contact you selected.

To a group

Control-click a group and choose “Send Email” from the pop-up menu.

Related Topics
Invite contacts to an iCal event
Invite contacts to text chats
Make a FaceTime video call
adrbk1524.name: Send email messages
adrbk1524.summary: Click the label of the email address field and choose Send Email from the pop-up menu.

adrbk1525.alternativeName: Display contacts by first or last name
adrbk1525.content:
Display contacts by first or last name

You can choose to display contacts in your address book with the first or last name listed first.

For all cards

  1. Choose Address Book > Preferences, and then click General.
  2. Choose to show the first name either before or after the last name.

For a specific card

Select the card, and then from the Card menu, choose either Reorder Last Name Before First or Reorder First Name Before Last.

The order of names for the card will now be independent of the General preferences setting.
adrbk1525.name: Display contacts by first or last name
adrbk1525.summary: You can change the order of the first and last name for a single card or for all contacts.

adrbk1530.content:
Display contacts or groups

You can display a list of contacts, a single contact, or a group.

Display a list of contacts

Choose View > “List and Card” or, if you’re viewing a single card, click the “List and Card” button at the bottom of the Address Book window.

Display one contact

Select a contact and choose View > Card Only, or click the Card button at the bottom of the Address Book window.

To view the next or previous card, use the arrow buttons at the bottom of the window.

Display a contact in a separate window

Double-click a contact in the list, or select a contact and choose Card > “Open in Separate Window.”

This method is useful when you want to display multiple contacts at one time. You can edit contact information in, and email contacts from, the separate window.

Display groups

  1. Choose View > Groups, or click the Groups icon at the top of the Address Book window, to view a list of available groups and directory services.
  2. Select a group to display a list of its contacts. To display contacts in a directory service, search the service.

    Use network directory services

If Address Book can’t connect to a server where contacts are stored, it displays a lightning bolt icon to the right of the group name in the Groups list.

Use the search field to find and display specific contacts or groups.

Search for contacts

Related Topics
Display contacts by first or last name
Display phone numbers in large type
Share address cards by email
adrbk1530.name: Display contacts or groups
adrbk1530.summary: Switch between displaying single contacts, or a list of all contacts and groups.

adrbk1532.alternativeName: If Address Book can’t save your changes
adrbk1532.content:
If Address Book can’t save your changes

If you have low disk space, you can’t save the changes you’ve made to your address book.

To solve the problem, delete some files on your computer to free disk space, or close some applications. Then try again to save your changes.
adrbk1532.name: If Address Book can’t save your changes
adrbk1532.summary: Try deleting some files or close some applications to free enough disk space for Address Book to save your changes.

adrbk1533.alternativeName: If Address Book has permissions problems
adrbk1533.content:
If Address Book has permissions problems

If you can’t open your address book because of a permissions error, you might be able to resolve the problem by setting permissions for your Library folder.

  1. In the Finder, choose Go > “Go to Folder,” type ~/Library, and then click Go.
  2. Choose File > Get Info.
  3. In the Sharing & Permissions pane, verify that you’re the owner and that you have Read & Write access privileges.

    You may need to click the disclosure triangle to display permissions details.

  4. Click the lock icon at the bottom of the pane, if necessary, and then click the Action pop-up menu (looks like a gear).
  5. Click “Apply to enclosed items” to apply these settings to all the files and folders in your Library folder.
adrbk1533.name: If Address Book has permissions problems
adrbk1533.summary: Try to resolve Address Book permissions problem by setting permissions for your Library folder.

adrbk1536.content:
Add phonetic spelling for contacts

If you have trouble remembering how to pronounce a contact’s name, you can add a field to the contact’s card and use it to enter the phonetic spelling for the name.

  1. Display the contact’s card.

    Display contacts or groups

  2. Choose Card > Add Field > Phonetic First/Last Name.

    The fields appear under the contact’s name at the top of the card.

  3. In the phonetic fields, enter tips for pronouncing the first and last name of the contact.

This feature is also useful when you’re entering names that use characters different from those used in your own language. For example, if you use English on your computer, enter a Japanese name in Japanese characters and an English phonetic spelling. The name appears in the list in its original characters but is sorted alphabetically by its phonetic spelling.
adrbk1536.name: Add phonetic spelling for contacts
adrbk1536.summary: Add a field to enter the phonetic spelling of a contact’s name.

adrbk1561.alternativeName: Sync contacts using MobileMe or iTunes
adrbk1561.content:
Sync contacts using MobileMe or iTunes

You can sync contacts using your MobileMe subscription or iTunes so that each device you use (iPhone, iPad, or iPod) has the same information.

Using MobileMe

You must repeat these steps on each computer you want to sync with your contacts.

  1. Choose Apple menu > System Preferences, and then click MobileMe.

    If you’re not already signed in to your MobileMe account, sign in.

  2. Click Sync, select the “Synchronize with MobileMe” checkbox, and then choose how often you want to sync from the pop-up menu.
  3. Select the Contacts checkbox in the list.
  4. To immediately sync, click Sync Now.

    To include a Sync menu in your Mac computer’s menu bar that you can use to sync at any time, select the “Show Sync status in menu bar” checkbox.

You can’t sync contacts in CardDAV, Exchange, or Yahoo! accounts; instead, you must add the accounts to each computer you want to use.

Using iTunes

  1. Connect your iPhone, iPad, or iPod to your computer.

    If iTunes doesn’t open automatically, open iTunes.

    Open iTunes

  2. Select your device, click the Info (or Contacts) tab, and then select the “Sync Address Book contacts” checkbox.
  3. Select whether to sync all contacts or only the groups you select.
  4. Select any other options you want, and then click Apply.

If you have a MobileMe account, you can move it to iCloud. To learn more, see:

MobileMe to iCloud transition FAQ

Related Topics
Access contacts using iCloud
Sync contacts with Google Contacts
Sync contacts with Yahoo! Address Book
adrbk1561.name: Sync contacts using MobileMe or iTunes
adrbk1561.summary: Use MobileMe or iTunes to sync contacts so that each device you use (iPhone, iPad, or iPod) has the same information.

adrbk1562.content:
Print contact information

You can use the information in your address book to print mailing labels, envelopes, a list of contacts, or a pocket address book.

Note: If you want to print envelopes, first make sure your printer is configured to print them and then place envelopes in the printer.

Print information

  1. Select one or more contacts or a group.

    If contacts in a group have multiple email or street addresses, or phone numbers, you can choose which addresses or phone number to use.

    Select addresses for group members

  2. Choose File > Print.
  3. Choose the style to print from the Style pop-up menu, and then set related options.

    If you don’t see the Style pop-up menu, click Show Details at the bottom of the Print dialog.

    OptionDescription
    Mailing labels: Click Layout and choose a label type from the Page pop-up menu. To set the page margins and the gutter space between labels, and how many labels to print on a page, choose Define Custom.

    Click Label and then choose the type of address to print for each contact from the Addresses pop-up menu (for example, print a label for each contact’s home or work address, or both). Use other Label options to specify the print order, to include a company (for business mailings) or a country (for international mailings), or to add a small graphic to the labels.

    Envelopes: Click Layout and choose the type of envelope you’re using from the Layout pop-up menu. If you’re using a non-standard envelope size, choose Define Custom, and then specify the envelope dimensions.

    Click Label and then specify whether to include your return address and which address to use for it. Choose the type of address to print for each contact from the Addresses pop-up menu (for example, print a label for each contact’s home or work address, or both).

    Use other Label options to choose the print order, to include a company (for business mailings) or a country (for international mailings), or to add a small graphic to the upper-left corner of the envelopes.

    To choose the direction in which to feed the envelopes into the printer, click Orientation.

    Lists: Select the paper size and orientation, and then use the Attributes list to select which fields to include.
    Pocket Address Book: Select the paper size and orientation, and then use the Attributes list to select which fields to include. Choose between the indexed and compact formats using the Flip Style option.

Tips for printing a pocket book

  • Up to six pocket-size pages fit on one 8.5-by-11 inch (US letter) sheet of paper. The page width of an indexed-style address book is determined by the total number of contacts you’re printing. Because the tabs are indented on each subsequent page, longer address books require wider pages.
  • If Address Book can’t fit all of the selected contacts in your pocket address book, try choosing a larger paper size, using compact instead of indexed style, selecting fewer attributes, or including fewer contacts.
  • When you cut out the individual pages of your pocket address book, follow the cut lines on the printed sheets.

You can’t print directly from directory services. To print address book information for contacts in directory services, drag the contacts to an On My Mac group.

Related Topics
Display contacts or groups
adrbk1562.name: Print contact information
adrbk1562.summary: Print mailing labels, envelopes, a list of contacts, or a pocket address book.

adrbk1564.content:
Use network directory services

If your computer is set up to access network directory services, such as an Exchange Global Address List (GAL), Address Book displays those directory services. The directories also appear in the Address Panel in Mail and iChat. The names of contacts in a directory service appear only when you search for contacts.

Search directory services for contacts

  1. Make sure you’re connected to the server on which the directory resides.

    If you changed locations or lost your network connection, Address Book can’t look up contacts from the directory. An Exchange account that’s offline is indicated by a lightning bolt icon after the account name.

  2. Select a directory from the list of groups.

    Display contacts or groups

  3. Enter text in the search field.

    The Exchange server limits search results to 100 contacts. Make sure your search text is specific enough to return the results you need.

Add a directory contact to your address book

Drag the contact to any group that is not a directory service.

Related Topics
Display contacts or groups
adrbk1564.name: Use network directory services
adrbk1564.summary: Contacts in a network directory service appear only when you search the directory.

adrbk1572.content:
Show a contact’s groups

You can quickly see all the groups and Smart Groups that one contact or several contacts belong to.

  1. When viewing groups, select one or more contacts.

    Display contacts or groups

  2. Hold down the Option key.

    Address Book highlights every group the selected contact, or all of the selected contacts, belong to. If you have a lot of groups, scroll the list to see all of the highlighted groups.

Related Topics
Create groups or folders
adrbk1572.name: Show a contact’s groups
adrbk1572.summary: See all the groups to which a contact belongs.

adrbk1578.alternativeName: Show birthdays on an iCal calendar
adrbk1578.content:
Show birthdays on an iCal calendar

You can keep track of contacts’ birthdays by creating a birthday calendar that automatically includes all the birthdays in your address book.

  1. In Address Book, make sure you’ve entered the birth date for each contact whose birthday you want to track.
  2. Open iCal, and then choose iCal > Preferences.

    Open iCal

  3. In the General pane, select the “Show Birthdays calendar” checkbox.

    Birthdays in your address book are automatically added to the Birthdays calendar in iCal. When you add or remove birthday information in Address Book, the Birthdays calendar is updated.

You can add the Birthday field to a single card or to all cards (by changing the template).

Related Topics
Add important dates
Change labels on a card
adrbk1578.name: Show birthdays on an iCal calendar
adrbk1578.summary: The iCal Birthdays calendar automatically includes all birthdays in your address book.

offline-message-com-apple-AddressBook-he.content:
The selected topic is currently unavailable

Make sure you’re connected to the Internet. For help connecting, choose Apple menu > System Preferences, click Network, and click “Assist me.”

If you’re connected to the Internet, and the content still doesn’t appear, try again later.
